page.title: 15Footpaths around Swyncombe
page.content: The area is criss-crossed by footpaths, many were probably routes of access for the villagers in the valleys to reach the upper beechwoods and find pannage for their pigs. Many tracks are well documented and various associations have clearly marked footpaths for the casual walker or the more dedicated rambler. The footpaths combine spectacular escarpment downland at Swyncombe with the beechwood covered deep folds of the Chiltern hills at Howe Hill, Christmas Common, Pishill and Maidensgrove and common land at Russells Water. The beechwoods are carpeted with bluebells in mid-May. Stinging nettles may overgrow some paths in the summer but the views are splendid in autumn when the leaves turn golden red, then brown. The Ridgeway Path is now a national footpath which follows a pre-Roman trading route.
